arm_group.description: cord clamping delayed by 30 to 60 seconds

brief_summary.textblock:
RESEARCH HYPOTHESIS Brief delay(>30 sec  to <60 sec ) in cord clamping as compared to early
      cord clamping (< 20 sec)  leads to a better short term neurobehavioural outcome in preterm
      (34-36 wks) neonates  when assessed  by neurobehavioral assessment of preterm infants
      (n.a.p.i.) at 37 weeks of post conceptional  age

clinical_study.brief_title: Brief Delay in Cord Clamping and Neurobehaviour in Preterms

detailed_description.textblock:
Delayed cord clamping (DCC) : Well described phenomenon in term infants .

        -  The optimal timing of clamping of umbilical  cord in preterm infants : A subject of
           debate.

        -  Even a  brief delay in cord clamping leads to an additional transfer of iron amounting
           to 40-50 mg/kg which may prevent iron deficiency.¹

        -  This low cost intervention can have significant public health importance in resource
           constrained settings.

        -  The effect of this intervention on neurobehaviour of preterm neonates has not been
           assessed.

        -  This aspect has been identified by WHO and Cochrane as a potentially  researchable
           area

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  All preterm deliveries -infants born at 34 weeks 0 days  to 36  weeks +6 days
             gestational age as estimated by last menstrual period or early ultrasound  scan.

          -  Infants delivered vaginally or by caesarean section in cephalic presentation

          -  Singleton pregnancy

          -  Parental consent

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Fetus with gross congenital anomaly

          -  Fetus with hydrops

          -  Rh negative pregnancy

intervention.description: delay in cord clamping 30 to 60 seconds

clinical_study.official_title: A Randomised Controlled Trial to Evaluate the Role of Brief Delay in Cord Clamping in Preterm Neonates (34-36weeks) on Short Term Neurodevelopmental Outcome

overall_official.affiliation: lady hardinge medical college new delhi

primary_outcome.description: using N.A.P.I (neurobehavioural assessment of preterm infant)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Diagnostic
